quote: Veni, vidi, made Some Spring Stuff

content.text: This was a project that I had to complete for my A-Level acreditation. This was my EPQ

Some Spring Stuff was my attempt to create a guide for people that want to get into web development. The idea was that it would focus on the people that have only understood the basics of Java language.

The website describe many different essential Spring concepts by showing how to create a very simple project. The idea is that people are shown code lines and that the logic behind each one is explained.

list: Node JS (used only to make a simple backend, I promise!)

paragraphs.heading: What part of the project I completed

content.text: I wrote all of the text for the website. I have spent over 3 months researching and trying to understand the most basic and essential components of the technology. Then I was attempting to put every piece of knowledge I gained into a comprehensive guide.

After that I began creating a website. I had no understanding how to make one, so I spent 2-3 months attempting my best to make a website using plain HTML and CSS. Was one of the most misserable experiences of my life, not gonna lie.

paragraphs.heading: How to get a look at this wonderful project

content.text: Here is a link (if you dare to see):

paragraphs.heading: Interesting things I learned doing project

content.text: For this project I tried something totally new for me: I tried to teach others how to do things. I am thankful to Some Spring Stuff for a number of reasons. Firstly, it taught me a lot about Sprinng Framework. Many aspects of that technology seemed too obscure when I was making my own code. But after searching for things to make the website a lot has clarified.

Secondly, I learned that I am not that great of a programming instructor yet. I decided to take a pause in that, get a degree first before teachinng others how to code. That is if I will want to teach. or if I will want to get a degree, for that matter.
